question.title: GridDB time-series query skips rows with millisecond timestamps (Java API)
question.body:
I'm testing GridDB Community Edition 5.3 (Linux container via Docker Desktop on macOS 14.4, Apple M1).

When I insert rows with millisecond timestamps into a time-series container, and query using a range, one of the rows is getting skipped even though it's clearly within the time range.

Here’s a reproducible Java example:

import java.sql.Timestamp;
import java.util.*;

public class MillisGapDemo {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        Properties p = new Properties();
        p.setProperty("clusterName", "defaultCluster");
        p.setProperty("notificationAddress", "239.0.0.1");
        p.setProperty("notificationPort", "31999");
        p.setProperty("user", "admin");
        p.setProperty("password", "admin");
        GridStore gs = GridStoreFactory.getInstance().getGridStore(p);

        ContainerInfo info = new ContainerInfo();
        info.setType(ContainerType.TIME_SERIES);
        info.setRowKeyAssigned(true);
        info.setColumnInfoList(List.of(
            new ColumnInfo("ts", GSType.TIMESTAMP),
            new ColumnInfo("value", GSType.DOUBLE)
        ));
        TimeSeries<Row> ts = gs.putTimeSeries("millis_test", info, true);

        ts.put(Arrays.asList(
            createRow(ts, Timestamp.valueOf("2023-01-01 10:00:00.500"), 25.0),
            createRow(ts, Timestamp.valueOf("2023-01-01 10:00:01.000"), 26.0)
        ));

        RowSet<Row> rs = ts.query(
            "SELECT * WHERE ts >= TIMESTAMP('2023-01-01 10:00:00') AND ts < TIMESTAMP('2023-01-01 10:00:02')"
        ).fetch();

        System.out.println("Rows returned: " + rs.size());
    }

    private static Row createRow(TimeSeries<Row> ts, Timestamp t, double v) {
        Row r = ts.createRow();
        r.setTimestamp(0, t);
        r.setDouble(1, v);
        return r;
    }
}

Expected: Both rows (10:00:00.500 and 10:00:01.000) should be returned
Actual: Only the 10:00:01.000 row is returned — the 10:00:00.500 row is skipped

What I’ve tried:

  • Using different comparison operators (>=, <, >, <=) — same issue
  • Switched between java.sql.Timestamp and java.util.Date
  • Used TIMESTAMPADD(MICROSECOND, …) in query — still skips the first row
  • Set timezone explicitly in the client (timeZone = "+00:00")

Questions:

  1. Does GridDB round or truncate timestamps internally to microseconds?
  2. Is there a best practice for querying time ranges with millisecond precision?
  3. Could this be a client vs. server timezone mismatch?
  4. How can I reliably return all rows in a sub-second time range?

question_comments.body: Switched between java.sql.Timestamp and java.util.Date Both of those classes are hopelessly badly designed and fortunately obsolete since Java 8. Would GridDB support Instant, OffsetDateTime, LocalDateTime or some other java.time type? java.time is the modern Java date and time API.
